questions.text: Galactomannan in serum is seen in: Invasive aspergillosis Systemic candidiasis Mucormycosis Histoplasma capsulatm
questions.explanation:
β-1,3-D-glucan

Galactomannan

Polysaccharide cell wall component

Major polysaccharide component of aspergillus cell wall.

Routinely used for : Candida, Aspergillus

Routinely used for : Aspergillus

Positive in: PJP, Histoplasma, Fusarium, Scedosporium, dermatophytes, Cocci

Positive in: Fusarium, Penicillium, Histoplasma, Blastomyces, Paecilomyces, cryptococcus

Negative in: Blastomyces, Mucor, Cryptococcus

Negative in: Mucorales

questions.text: Identify the pathognomic structure given in the slide below
questions.explanation:
Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis)

Epidemiology

It is the most common form of chromomycosis.

Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.

Tropical region.

Causative agents

Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora.

Route of transmission

Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation.

Clinical manifestation

Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower).

Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs

Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy: The lesions show the presence of the fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate, called sclerotic bodies (other names: muriform bodies, copper pennies, medlar bodies).

Demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Treatment

Medical: Amphotericin B, thiabendazole, 5-fluoro cytosine, itraconazole and (new drug) voriconazole.

Surgical excision.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest. Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branch filaments like a ‘Spaghetti and meatball appearance’ as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation:
Test/Tool

Findings

Microscopy (Skin Scrapings)

Abundant yeast cells and short, branched filaments (yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments)

Spaghetti and meatball appearance under KOH microscopy

Culture

Grown on Sabouraud agar with an olive oil overlay.

Wood’s Lamp Exam

Infected areas fluoresce golden-yellow under UV light.

questions.text: What is the primary risk factor for the disease in a patient who exhibits symptoms of a black, malodorous nasal discharge, along with the presence of a black, necrotic mass that fills the nasal cavity and causes erosion of the septum and hard palate during examination?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

 

 

Absidia Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.

Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.

Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features

Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:

Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.

Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.

Pulmonary Zygomycosis:

Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.

Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:

Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.

Medical control of diabetes is required.

questions.text: A COVID patient presented with fever, nasal congestion, and unilateral headache. Later, he developed facial pain and numbness, along with a blackish lesion. On Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA), a cotton-wooly growth is seen. H&E staining shows non-septate hyphae branching at right angles/obtuse angles. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus:

 Absidia

 Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained):

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. 

b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

 

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism.
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent?

options.label: A
options.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis

options.label: B
options.text: Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium

options.label: D
options.text: Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.correct_answer: D. Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus
questions.explanation:
Morphology of different Fungi

Fungi

Morphology 

Microscopy 

Aspergillus (Option D)

Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae + septate h hi yphae

Mucor and Rhizopus species

(Option A and C)

Broad, aseptate hyphae branching at 90 degree or more

Candida

Single-cell with or without pseudohyphae

questions.text: Which of the following is the probable cause in a case of tinea capitis where white powdery colonies were obtained from the hair specimen and the hair perforation test was positive on the isolate?
questions.explanation:
Method

Description

Macroscopic examination

Assess the growth rate, texture, and colour on media

Urea hydrolysis test

Determines ability to hydrolyze urea

Growth on polished rice or special media

Tests the ability to grow in specific conditions

Temperature tolerance test

Assesses resistance to elevated temperatures

Nutritional requirements test

Checks requirements for specific amino acids and vitamins

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago presents with diarrhea for 9 days. A stool sample subjected to Kinyoun stain reveals 4-6 μm structures. Which of the following is true about the organism?
questions.correct_answer: C. Sporozoites adhere to intestinal mucosa
questions.explanation:
Life Cycle of Cryptosporidium

1. Ingestion of Infective Oocysts: Humans or animals ingest fully mature (sporulated) oocysts from contaminated water, food, or surfaces.

2. Excystation: In the host’s small intestine, the oocyst releases four sporozoites, which then attach to the intestinal epithelial cells.

3. Trophozoite Formation: The sporozoites develop into trophozoites within parasitophorous vacuoles (specialised compartments) in the brush border of the host’s intestinal cells.

4. Asexual Reproduction (Schizogony): Trophozoites undergo asexual reproduction to form type I meronts, each containing eight merozoites.

5. Release of Merozoites: The merozoites are released, infect new epithelial cells, and may undergo schizogony again to form more type I meronts or transition into type II meronts.

6. Sexual Reproduction (Gametogony): Type II meronts release merozoites that invade cells and begin the sexual phase, differentiating into microgametes (male) and macrogametes (female).

7. Fertilization and Oocyst Formation: The microgamete fertilises the macrogamete, forming a zygote that then develops into an oocyst.

8. Sporulation: The zygote undergoes sporogony to form a fully mature, sporulated oocyst containing four sporozoites.

9. Release of Oocysts: Two types of oocysts are produced:

  • Thick-walled oocysts: Excreted in faeces, they are mature and infective and transmit the infection to new hosts.
  • Thin-walled oocysts: Remain in the intestine and cause autoinfection, maintaining the cycle within the same host.

10. Transmission: Thick-walled oocysts are released into the environment through faeces, where they can infect new hosts upon ingestion.

Both sexual and asexual reproduction occurs within one host

Cryptosporidium

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst in contaminated water

Clinical features

  • In Immunocompetent patients: Self-limited watery diarrhoea.
  • In Immunocompromised patients: Chronic persistent watery diarrhoea.

Microscopy

  • Appearance: Acid-fast, round oocyst
  • Size: 4–6 microns
  • Contents: Each oocyst contains four sporozoites
  • Types of oocyst:
    • Thick-walled - excreted out from host in faeces.
    • Thin-walled - involved in autoinfection.

 

Isospora

Cyclospora

Sarcocystis

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Clinical features

  • Mild fever with diarrhoea
  • Can cause chronic diarrhoea in the immunocompromised host
  • Formation of sarcocysts within the muscle fibres (Muscular sarcocystosis)
  • Nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhoea (Intestinal sarcocystosis)

Microscopy

Oocyte is oval, acid-fast, 24-36 microns and autofluorescent, containing 8 sporozoites.

 

Oocyte is round, acid variable, 8-10 microns and autofluorescent, containing 2 - 2 sporozoites in each wheel.

Sarcocysts are present between the muscle fibres; each cyst has numerous merozoites.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common foot infection caused due to walking barefoot?
questions.explanation:
Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.

 

Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).

 

Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp.

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

 

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Lead to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment

Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.

C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

Feature

Oral Candidiasis

Hairy Leukoplakia

Lichen Planus

Diphtheria

Cause

Candida albicans

Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)

Autoimmune

Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Appearance

White, curd-like plaques

White, corrugated plaques

Reticular white striae

Grayish pseudomembrane

Scrapable

Yes

No

No

No (bleeds on removal)

Microscopy

Budding yeasts, pseudohyphae

No fungal elements

No fungal elements

Gram-positive rods

Seen in HIV

Yes, common in immunocompromised

Yes

Rare

No

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.
  • Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.
  • Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: An AIDS-positive patient came with a history of fever, vomiting, and meningismus. Which of the following tests help in the rapid diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis?

options.label: D
options.text: Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen

questions.correct_answer: D. Urine lateral flow assay for cryptococcal antigen
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system

  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Urine Lateral Flow Assay for Cryptococcal Antigen- Best rapid diagnostic test.

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.explanation:
Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increases susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Lead to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.
  • C. krusei- Resistant to azoles

questions.text: Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Clinical Type

Description

Tinea barbae

Infection of the bearded areas of the face and neck (barber's itch).

Tinea capitis

Infection of the scalp; variants include favus and kerion.

Tinea corporis

Infection of smooth, non-hairy skin (Tinea glabrosa).

Tinea cruris

Infection of the groin and perineum (jock itch).

Tinea imbricata

Tropical variant of Tinea corporis with concentric scaly patches.

Tinea manuum

Infection of the hand.

Tinea pedis

Infection of the foot (athlete's foot).

Tinea unguium

Infection of the nails.

Genus

Key Characteristics

Microsporum

Predominantly macroconidia; spindle-shaped, multicellular structures; infects hair and skin. (Option B ruled out)

Trichophyton

More abundant microconidia in clusters; macroconidia are thin, and elongated; include species like T. rubrum which is common in humans. Infects hair, nails and skin. (Option A ruled out)

Epidermophyton

Lacks microconidia; club-shaped, multicellular macroconidia; infects skin and nails but not hair. (Option C) (Option D ruled out)

Features

Trichophyton

Microsporum

Epidermophyton

1. Site of infection

Hair, nail, and skin

Hair and skin only

Skin and nail only

2. Colony

Powdery pigmented

Cotton-like pigmented

Powdery greenish yellow

3. Spores

a. Microconidia

Abundant

Relatively scanty

Absent

b. Macroconidia

Pencil or cylindrical-shaped

Spindle-shaped

Club or pear-shaped

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Cryptococcus

Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis .

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors

  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.

  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.

  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:

    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.

    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells

  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture

  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.

  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.

  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine

  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.

  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.

  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Ohio presents to a physician with a chronic cough. A chest x-ray demonstrates a cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the lymph node and staining with lactophenol cotton blue demonstrates the following characteristics as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Histoplasmosis:

Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum, are helpful for immunocompromised individuals

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole

questions.text: In patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, which type of fungus is frequently linked to orbital cellulitis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Rhizopu

questions.text: A farmer presented with the history of blunt trauma to the chest. Microscopy of the sample showed mildly acid-fast bacteria with branching.Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Features

Actinomycetes

Nocardia

Acid-fastness

Nonacid-fast

Partially acid-fast

O2 Requirement

Anaerobe

Obligate aerobe

Habitat
  • Found as oral flora
  • Infections occur endogenously
  • The usual habitat is the soil
  • Infections occur exogenously

Risk factors

Immunocompetent also

Usually only in immunocompromised

Clinical forms

Cervicofascial, abdominal, and others.

Pulmonary, CNS forms, Actinomycetoma

Granules

Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli, and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance)
  • Granules are soft and lobulated and also show a sun-ray appearance
  • Commonly found in mycetoma, rare in other conditions

Culture
  • Spidery molar teeth colony in solid media
  • Fluffy ball at the bottom of the liquid medium
  • Colonies are creamy, wrinkled, and pink Isolation is done in
  • Selective media
  • Paraffin bait technique
  • LJ medium

Treatment

Penicillin

Cotrimoxazole

questions.text: A gardener with lymphogranulomatous lesions presented to the OPD, Identify the organism shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features

Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.

Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.

Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
 
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.
 

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

 

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: TRUE about cryptococcus
questions.explanation:
Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis .

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
  • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
  • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

 

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 139 cells/μL presents with altered sensorium and impaired consciousness. CSF examination using an India ink preparation reveals a positive result. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Cryptococcosis

Respiratory System

  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection / pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to the involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones maybe involved in disseminated infections

Diagnosis of Cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink: Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells

  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci.

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: A person came with the H/o thorn prick a week ago. A few days later, he developed ulcers along lymphatic drainage. Choose the correct organism.
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of Transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

​​​​​​​

 

  • Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.
  • Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)

  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells. (Option C)

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Cryptococcal meningitis. What is the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Causes
  • Cryptococcus neoformans (most common)
  • Candida
  • Histoplasma
  • Blastomyces
  • Coccidioides
  • Sporothrix

Risk factors

Immunocompromised patients

Clinical features
  • Headache
  • Altered mental status, lethargy
  • Fever
  • Neck stiffness
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Investigations
  • Lumbar Puncture: Low glucose and high protein levels. White cell count can be normal or higher than 20 microL and have a lymphocyte predominance.
  • India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells.
  • CSF ELISA for CRAG (Cryptococcal Antigen).

Treatment
  • LAMB (Liposomal Amphotericin-B) and 5-Fluorocytosine (Flucytosine) for 2 weeks
  • Fluconazole is given subsequently for 8-10 weeks.

questions.text: Which disease is commonly referred to as "Desert Rheumatism"?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - C

questions.text: Which organism is associated with broad-based budding?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - B

questions.text: A central line infection is noted in an ICU patient, and staining shows a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism:
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - C

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a positive india ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis.

Serotypes

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture

  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci.

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine

questions.text: Identify the given organism?
questions.explanation:
Genus

Key Characteristics

Microsporum

Predominantly macroconidia; spindle-shaped, multicellular structures; infects hair and skin.

Trichophyton

More abundant microconidia in clusters; macroconidia are thin, and elongated; include species like T. rubrum which is common in humans. Infects hair, nails and skin.

Epidermophyton

Lacks microconidia; club-shaped, multicellular macroconidia; infects skin and nails but not hair.

Features

Trichophyton

Microsporum

Epidermophyton

1. Site of infection

Hair, nail, and skin

Hair and skin only

Skin and nail only

2. Colony

Powdery pigmented

Cotton-like pigmented

Powdery greenish yellow

3. Spores

a. Microconidia

Abundant

Relatively scanty

Absent

b. Macroconidia

Pencil or cylindrical-shaped

(Option D ruled out)

Spindle-shaped

(Option A & B ruled out)

Club or pear-shaped

Habitat Type

Characteristics

Examples

Anthropophilic

Primarily found in humans; causes mild, chronic lesions.

T. rubrum, E. floccosum, M. audouinii

Zoophilic

Natural parasites of animals; cause severe inflammation but are treatable.

T. verrucosum, M. canis

Geophilic

Found in soil; less pathogenic to humans.

M. gypseum, T. ajelloi

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms is likely responsible for causing bilateral infiltrates in an HIV-positive patient?
questions.explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

Transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

 

 

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

questions.text: A patient with pneumonia provides a BAL sample, as shown below. What is the likely pathogen responsible, and what is the relative management?
questions.explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

Transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

 

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

questions.text: The below slide represents a gomori methenamine silver stained slide with acute angle branching and septate hyphae. What is the organism?
questions.explanation:
Morphology of different fungi

Fungi

Morphology 

Microscopy 

Aspergillus

Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae + septate h hi yphae

Mucor and Rhizopus species

(Option D)

Broad, aseptate hyphae branching at 90 degree or more

Candida

(Option B)

Single-cell with or without pseudohyphae

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of facial pain, swelling, and nasal discharge. The patient was recently hospitalized for a COVID-19 infection and treated with a prolonged course of steroids. Examination of the nasal discharge under the microscope shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus:

Absidia:

Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained):

 

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

Features

Aspergillus

Mucor

Branching

<45°

>90° or 90°

Hyphae

Septate

Aseptate

Shape

Thin

Broad ribbon-like

questions.text: A man has undergone a renal transplant and is taking immunosuppressant drugs. On biopsy, gram positive budding cells with pseudohyphae are observed. What is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation:
Laboratory diagnosis of candida

Germ tube test
  • The germ tube test is a specific diagnostic test for Candida albicans.
  • Germ tube also seen in candida dubliniensis
  • Candida tropicalis- pseudo germ tube formation

 

Also known as Reynolds Braude Phenomenon

Candida + Human serum → Incubation → Big tube-like structure (Pseudohyphae).

 

Gram stain

Yeast-like organism - Has both buds and pseudohyphae.

 

SDA Culture media test

Colonies are creamy white, smooth and with a yeasty odor

Corn meal agar test

 

Forms chlamydospores on corn meal agar cultures at 20°C -identified by double wall configuration.

 

Chrom agar test

Colour differentiation test

Each type of organism is seen differently

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a skin infection characterized by itching, redness, and scaling. Microscopic examination of a skin sample reveals a pencil-shaped appearance. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism responsible for this skin infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Trichophyton

questions.text: A 46-year-old farmer present with a traumatic ulcer in the eye. Microscopic examination reveals septate hyphae at an acute angle. Which of the following will be the causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Asperg

questions.text: A patient presented with persistent dry cough, fever, and weight loss. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months ago but has been poorly adherent to medications. Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) staining of bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) reveals a crushed ping-pong ball appearance. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

HIV-Infected Patients

Non-HIV Patients

Onset

Gradual (2 weeks to 2 months)

Sudden (within a week)

Symptom Severity

Milder respiratory distress initially

Rapid progression to respiratory failure

Course

Chronic

Acute

Oxygen Impairment

Less severe

More severe

  • Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Diagnosis

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of …………….
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Candida A

questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Mu

questions.text: A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body, as shown in the image, was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Sporothrix Schenck

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying Cryptococcus ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Mucicarmine S

questions.text: A patient presented with wart-like lesions on exposed areas of the skin, such as the legs or forearms . Histopathology of the wart revealed findings as shown in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B

questions.text: Which of the following exists in yeast form at 37ºC and hyphal form at 25ºC?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Histoplasma Capsulatu

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Sporothrix Schenck

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a farmer who has a wart-like skin growth on his foot and histopathology of the growth is shown in the below image?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C -

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the below image . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - M

Feature

Actinomycetoma

Eumycetoma (Madura Foot)

Organism
  • Bacteria (gram +ve)
  • Fungus

Examples
  • Actinomadura madurae
  • Madurella mycetomatis

Granules
  • Red – Actinomadura pelletieri
  • Off white/yellow – Nocardia, Streptomyces, Actinomadura
  • Brown (Melanin) – Madurella exophiala
  • White (Hyaline) – Acremonium Pseudallescheria boydii
